Constans is a nickname given to the Emperor, who had been baptized Flavius Heraclius and reigned officially as "Constantine". The nickname established itself in Byzantine texts and has become standard in modern historiography.

heading: Births
txt: Ibn Hazm, Arabian philosopher and scholar (d. 1069)

entities.title: Ibn Hazm
entities.description: Abū Muḥammad ʿAlī ibn Aḥmad ibn Saʿīd ibn Ḥazm was an Andalusian Muslim polymath, historian, jurist, philosopher, and theologian, born in the Caliphate of Córdoba, present-day Spain. Described as one of the strictest hadith interpreters, Ibn Hazm was a leading proponent and codifier of the Zahiri school of Islamic thought and produced a reported 400 works, of which only 40 still survive. In all, h

heading: Births
txt: Ögedei Khan, Mongol ruler, 2nd Great Khan of the Mongol Empire (d. 1241)

entities.title: Ögedei Khan
entities.description: Ögedei was the third son of Genghis Khan and second khagan-emperor of the Mongol Empire, succeeding his father. He continued the expansion of the empire that his father had begun, and was a world figure when the Mongol Empire reached its farthest extent west and south during the Mongol invasions of Europe and East Asia. Like all of Genghis' primary sons, he participated extensively in conquests in

entities.title: Great Khan
entities.description: Khagan or Qaghan is a title of imperial rank in the Turkic, Mongolic and some other languages, equal to the status of emperor and someone who rules a khaganate (empire). The female equivalent is Khatun.

heading: Births
txt: Simeon of Russia (d. 1353)

entities.title: Simeon of Russia
entities.description: Simeon Ivanovich Gordiy  was Prince of Moscow and Grand Prince of Vladimir. Simeon continued his father's policies aimed to increase the power and prestige of his state. Simeon's rule was marked by regular military and political standoffs against the Novgorod Republic and the Grand Duchy of Lithuania. His relationships with neighboring Russian principalities remained peaceful if not passive: Simeo

heading: Births

entities.title: Margaret of Bavaria, Electress Palatine
entities.description: Margaret of Bavaria was a princess of Bavaria-Landshut and by marriage Princess of the Palatinate.

heading: Births
txt: Georg Cracow, German lawyer and politician (d. 1575)

entities.title: Georg Cracow
entities.description: Georg Cracow, Kraków, Cracov, Cracau or Cracovius was a German lawyer and statesman.

heading: Births
txt: Francisco de Zurbarán, Spanish painter (d. 1664)

entities.title: Francisco de Zurbarán
entities.description: Francisco de Zurbarán was a Spanish painter. He is known primarily for his religious paintings depicting monks, nuns, and martyrs, and for his still-lifes. Zurbarán gained the nickname "Spanish Caravaggio," owing to the forceful use of chiaroscuro in which he excelled.

heading: Births
txt: Gédéon Tallemant des Réaux, French author and poet (d. 1692)

entities.title: Gédéon Tallemant des Réaux
entities.description: Gédéon Tallemant, Sieur des Réaux was a French writer known for his Historiettes, a collection of short biographies.

heading: Births
txt: John Robinson, English bishop and diplomat (d. 1723)

entities.title: John Robinson (bishop of London)
entities.description: John Robinson was an English diplomat and prelate.

heading: Births
txt: Anton thor Helle, German-Estonian clergyman, author, and translator (d. 1748)

entities.title: Anton thor Helle
entities.description: Anton thor Helle was the translator of the first Bible in Estonian in 1739, and the first Estonian grammar. The New Testament was a North Estonian revision of the 1648 version by Johannes Gutslaff (d.1657) author of Observationes Grammaticae circa linguam Esthonicam, and Helle's version was revised many times, including by C. Malm in 1896.

heading: Births
txt: William Stukeley, English archaeologist and physician (d. 1765)

entities.title: William Stukeley
entities.description: William Stukeley was an English antiquarian, physician and Anglican clergyman. A significant influence on the later development of archaeology, he pioneered the scholarly investigation of the prehistoric monuments of Stonehenge and Avebury in Wiltshire. He published over twenty books on archaeology and other subjects during his lifetime.

heading: Births
txt: Carlo Cecere, Italian violinist and composer (d. 1761)

entities.title: Carlo Cecere
entities.description: Carlo Cecere was an Italian composer of operas, concertos and instrumental duets including, for example, some mandolin duets and a concerto for mandolin. Cecere worked in the transitional period between the Baroque and Classical eras.

heading: Births
txt: James Cook, English captain, navigator, and cartographer (d. 1779)

entities.title: James Cook
entities.description: Captain James Cook was a British explorer, navigator, cartographer, and captain in the British Royal Navy, famous for his three voyages between 1768 and 1779 in the Pacific Ocean and to Australia in particular. He made detailed maps of Newfoundland prior to making three voyages to the Pacific, during which he achieved the first recorded European contact with the eastern coastline of Australia and

heading: Births
txt: Friedrich Leopold zu Stolberg-Stolberg, German poet and lawyer (d. 1819)

entities.title: Friedrich Leopold zu Stolberg-Stolberg
entities.description: Friedrich Leopold Graf zu Stolberg-Stolberg, was a German poet, lawyer, and translator born at Bramstedt in Holstein.

heading: Births
txt: Carl Carl, Polish-born actor and theatre director (d. 1854)

entities.title: Carl Carl
entities.description: Karl Andreas Bernbrunn (1787–1854), known by the stage name Carl Carl, was a Kraków-born actor and theatre director.

heading: Births
txt: Alfred Kelley, American legislator, canal builder, and railroad magnate (d. 1859)

entities.title: Alfred Kelley
entities.description: Alfred Kelley was a banker, canal builder, lawyer, railroad executive, and state legislator in the state of Ohio in the United States. He is considered by historians to be one of the most prominent commercial, financial, and political Ohioans of the first half of the 19th century.

heading: Births
txt: Platt Rogers Spencer, American calligrapher and educator (d. 1864)

entities.title: Platt Rogers Spencer
entities.description: Platt Rogers Spencer was the originator of Spencerian penmanship, a popular system of cursive handwriting. He was a teacher and active in the business school movement.

heading: Births
txt: Thomas Brassey, English engineer and businessman (d. 1870)

entities.title: Thomas Brassey
entities.description: Thomas Brassey was an English civil engineering contractor and manufacturer of building materials who was responsible for building much of the world's railways in the 19th century. By 1847, he had built about one-third of the railways in Britain, and by time of his death in 1870 he had built one in every twenty miles of railway in the world. This included three-quarters of the lines in France, maj

heading: Births
txt: Emil du Bois-Reymond, German physician and physiologist (d. 1896)

entities.title: Emil du Bois-Reymond
entities.description: Emil Heinrich du Bois-Reymond was a German physician and physiologist, the co-discoverer of nerve action potential, and the developer of experimental electrophysiology.

heading: Births
txt: Andrea Debono, Maltese trader and explorer (d. 1871)

entities.title: Andrea Debono
entities.description: Andrea Debono, also known as Latif Effendi, was a Maltese trader and explorer who was one of the first Europeans to explore the area around the White Nile in the mid-19th century.

heading: Births
txt: Emanuele Luigi Galizia, Maltese architect and civil engineer (d. 1907)

entities.title: Emanuele Luigi Galizia
entities.description: Emanuele Luigi Galizia was a Maltese architect and civil engineer, who designed many public buildings and several churches. He is regarded as "the principal Maltese architect throughout the second half of the nineteenth century".

heading: Births
txt: Andrew Dickson White, American historian, academic, and diplomat, co-founded Cornell University (d. 1918)

entities.title: Andrew Dickson White
entities.description: Andrew Dickson White was an American historian and educator who cofounded Cornell University and served as its first president for nearly two decades. He was known for expanding the scope of college curricula. A politician, he had served as state senator in New York. He was later appointed as an American diplomat to Germany and Russia, among other responsibilities.

entities.title: Cornell University
entities.description: Cornell University is a private, statutory, Ivy League and land-grant research university in Ithaca, New York. Founded in 1865 by Ezra Cornell and Andrew Dickson White, the university was intended to teach and make contributions in all fields of knowledge—from the classics to the sciences, and from the theoretical to the applied. These ideals, unconventional for the time, are captured in Cornell's

heading: Births
txt: Auguste Villiers de l'Isle-Adam, French author and playwright (d. 1889)

entities.title: Auguste Villiers de l'Isle-Adam
entities.description: Jean-Marie-Mathias-Philippe-Auguste, comte de Villiers de l'Isle-Adam was a French symbolist writer.

heading: Births
txt: William Plankinton, American businessman, industrialist and banker (d. 1905)

entities.title: William Plankinton
entities.description: William Plankinton was an American businessman, manufacturer, and industrialist. He followed in his father's footsteps in the meat packing and meat processing industry.

heading: Births
txt: Ignaz Brüll, Austrian pianist and composer (d. 1907)

entities.title: Ignaz Brüll
entities.description: Ignaz Brüll was a Moravian-born pianist and composer who lived and worked in Vienna.

heading: Births
txt: Chris von der Ahe, German-American businessman (d. 1913)

entities.title: Chris von der Ahe
entities.description: Christian Friedrich Wilhelm von der Ahe was a German-American entrepreneur, best known as the owner of the St. Louis Brown Stockings of the American Association, now known as the St. Louis Cardinals.

heading: Births
txt: Bipin Chandra Pal, Indian academic and activist (d. 1932)

entities.title: Bipin Chandra Pal
entities.description: Bipin Chandra Pal was an Indian nationalist, writer, orator, social reformer and Indian independence movement freedom fighter. He was one third of the “Lal Bal Pal” triumvirate. Pal was one of the main architects of the Swadeshi movement along with Sri Aurobindo. He stood against the partition of Bengal by the colonial British government.

heading: Births
txt: Jean Baptiste Eugène Estienne, French general and engineer (d. 1936)

entities.title: Jean Baptiste Eugène Estienne
entities.description: Jean Baptiste Eugène Estienne was a general of artillery and a specialist in military engineering, one of the founders of modern French artillery and French military aviation, and the creator of the French tank arm. He is considered by many in France to be the Père des Chars.

heading: Births
txt: Paul Peel, Canadian painter and academic (d. 1892)

heading: Births
txt: Jeff Milton, American police officer (d. 1947)

entities.title: Jeff Milton
entities.description: Jeff Milton was an Old West lawman and the son of the Confederate Governor of Florida, John Milton. Jefferson Davis Milton, a descendant of the Milton family that produced the English poet, John Milton, was the first officer appointed in the U.S. Immigration Service Border Patrol in 1924.

heading: Births
txt: Marie Curie, Polish chemist and physicist, Nobel Prize laureate (d. 1934)

entities.title: Marie Curie
entities.description: Marie Salomea Skłodowska Curie, born Maria Salomea Skłodowska, was a Polish and naturalized-French physicist and chemist who conducted pioneering research on radioactivity. As the first of the Curie family legacy of five Nobel Prizes, she was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize, the first person and the only woman to win the Nobel Prize twice, and the only person to win the Nobel Prize in two sci

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for mankind in the field of physics. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895 and awarded since 1901; the others being the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Nobel Prize in Literature, Nobel Peace Prize, and Nobel Pr

heading: Births
txt: Lucille La Verne, American actress (d. 1945)

entities.title: Lucille La Verne
entities.description: Lucille La Verne was an American stage and screen actress known for her appearances in silent, scolding, obnoxious, vituperative, sarcastic, cunning, and vengeful roles in early color films, as well as for her triumphs on the American stage. She is most widely remembered as the voice of the first Disney villain, the Evil Queen, Snow White's wicked stepmother from Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1

heading: Births
txt: Leonora Speyer, American poet and violinist (d. 1956)

heading: Births
txt: Charlie Townsend, English cricketer and lawyer (d. 1958)

entities.title: Charlie Townsend
entities.description: Charles Lucas Townsend was a Gloucestershire cricketer. An all-round cricketer, Townsend was classically stylish, left-handed batsman, who was able to hit well despite his slender build. His off-side strokes were particularly effective, and his driving allowed him to score at a consistent pace throughout his major innings. In his younger days Townsend was also a spin bowler, who relied chiefly on

heading: Births
txt: Lise Meitner, Austrian-Swedish physicist and academic (d. 1968)

entities.title: Lise Meitner
entities.description: Lise Meitner was an Austrian-Swedish physicist who contributed to the discoveries of the element protactinium and nuclear fission. While working at the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute on radioactivity, she discovered the radioactive isotope protactinium-231 in 1917. In 1938, Meitner and nephew-physicist Otto Robert Frisch discovered nuclear fission. She was praised by Albert Einstein as the "German Marie

heading: Births
txt: King Baggot, American actor, director, and screenwriter (d. 1948)

entities.title: King Baggot
entities.description: William King Baggot was an American actor, film director and screenwriter. He was an internationally famous movie star of the silent film era. The first individually publicized leading man in America, Baggot was referred to as "King of the Movies," "The Most Photographed Man in the World" and "The Man Whose Face Is As Familiar As The Man In The Moon."

heading: Births
txt: Leon Trotsky, Russian theorist and politician, founded the Red Army (d. 1940)

entities.title: Red Army
entities.description: The Workers' and Peasants' Red Army, frequently shortened to Red Army was the army and the air force of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic and, after 1922, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. The army was established immediately after the 1917 October Revolution. The Bolsheviks raised an army to oppose the military confederations of their adversaries during the Russian Civil War

heading: Births
txt: Aron Nimzowitsch, Russian-Danish chess player and theoretician (d. 1935)

entities.title: Aron Nimzowitsch
entities.description: Aron Nimzowitsch was a Latvian-born Danish chess player and writer. He was the foremost figure amongst the hypermoderns and wrote a very influential book on chess theory: My System. In the late 1920s, he was one of the best chess players in the world.

heading: Births
txt: C. V. Raman, Indian physicist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (d. 1970)

entities.title: C. V. Raman
entities.description: Sir Chandrasekhara Venkata Raman was an Indian physicist known mainly for his work in the field of light scattering. With his student K. S. Krishnan, he discovered that when light traverses a transparent material, some of the deflected light changes wavelength and amplitude. This phenomenon was a new type of scattering of light and was subsequently termed as the Raman effect. Raman won the 1930 No

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for mankind in the field of physics. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895 and awarded since 1901; the others being the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Nobel Prize in Literature, Nobel Peace Prize, and Nobel Pr

heading: Births
txt: Jan Matulka, Czech-American painter and illustrator (d. 1972)

entities.title: Jan Matulka
entities.description: Jan Matulka was a Czech-American modern artist originally from Bohemia. Matulka's style ranged from Abstract expressionism to landscapes, sometimes in the same day. He has directly influenced artists like Dorothy Dehner, Francis Criss, Burgoyne Diller, I. Rice Pereira, and David Smith.

heading: Births
txt: Genrikh Yagoda, director of the NKVD (d. 1938)

entities.title: Genrikh Yagoda
entities.description: Genrikh Grigoryevich Yagoda was a Soviet secret police official who served as director of the NKVD, the Soviet Union's security and intelligence agency, from 1934 to 1936. Appointed by Joseph Stalin, Yagoda supervised arrests, show trials, and executions of the Old Bolsheviks Lev Kamenev and Grigory Zinoviev, climactic events of the Great Purge. Yagoda also supervised construction of the White Sea

entities.title: NKVD
entities.description: The People's Commissariat for Internal Affairs, abbreviated NKVD, was the interior ministry of the Soviet Union.

heading: Births
txt: Leatrice Joy, American actress (d. 1985)

entities.title: Leatrice Joy
entities.description: Leatrice Joy was an American actress most prolific during the silent film era.

heading: Births
txt: Margaret Leech, American historian and author (d. 1974)

heading: Births
txt: Esdras Minville, Canadian economist and sociologist (d. 1975)

entities.title: Esdras Minville
entities.description: Esdras Minville was a Quebec writer, economist and sociologist. He served as the Dean of the Faculty of Social Sciences at the Université de Montréal, and was the first French-Canadian to serve as head of HEC Montréal. A staunch defender of Catholic social doctrine, Minville helped to found several co-operatives in the province.

heading: Births
txt: Herman J. Mankiewicz, American director, producer, and screenwriter (d. 1953)

entities.title: Herman J. Mankiewicz
entities.description: Herman Jacob Mankiewicz was an American screenwriter who, with Orson Welles, wrote the screenplay for Citizen Kane (1941). Earlier, he was a Berlin correspondent for Women’s Wear Daily, assistant theater editor at The New York Times, and the first regular drama critic at The New Yorker. txt: Armstrong Sperry, American author and illustrator (d. 1976)

heading: Births
txt: Margaret Morris, American actress (d. 1968)

entities.title: Margaret Morris (actress)
entities.description: Margaret Morris was an American film actress of the silent film era and into the 1930s.

heading: Births
txt: Raphaël Salem, Greek-French mathematician and academic (d. 1963)

heading: Births
txt: Yitzhak Lamdan, Russian-Israeli journalist and poet (d. 1954)

entities.title: Yitzhak Lamdan
entities.description: Yitzhak Lamdan was an Israeli Hebrew-language poet, translator, editor and columnist.

heading: Births
txt: Nellie Campobello, Mexican writer who chronicled the Mexican Revolution (d. 1986)

entities.title: Nellie Campobello
entities.description: Nellie Francisca Ernestina Campobello Luna was a Mexican writer, notable for having written one of the few chronicles of the Mexican Revolution from a woman's perspective. Cartucho chronicles her experience as a young girl in Northern Mexico at the height of the struggle between forces loyal to Pancho Villa and those who followed Venustiano Carranza. She moved to Mexico City in 1923, where she spe

entities.title: Mexican Revolution
entities.description: The Mexican Revolution was a major revolution that included a sequence of armed struggles that lasted roughly from 1910 to 1920 and transformed Mexican culture and government. The outbreak of the revolution in 1910 resulted from the increasing unpopularity of the 31-year regime of Porfirio Díaz and the regime's failure to find a controlled solution to the issue of presidential succession. That res

heading: Births
txt: Norah McGuinness, Irish painter and illustrator (d. 1980)

entities.title: Norah McGuinness
entities.description: Norah Allison McGuinness was an Irish painter and illustrator.

heading: Births
txt: Ary Barroso, Brazilian pianist and composer (d. 1964)

entities.title: Ary Barroso
entities.description: Ary de Resende Barroso (1903–1964), better known as Ary Barroso, was a Brazilian composer, pianist, soccer commentator, and talent-show host on radio and TV. He was one of Brazil's most successful songwriters in the first half of the 20th century. Barroso also composed many songs for Carmen Miranda during her career.

heading: Births

entities.description: The Chief Minister of Gujarat is the chief executive of the government of the Indian state of Gujarat. The governor appoints the chief minister, whose council of ministers are collectively responsible to the assembly. The chief minister's term is for five years and is subject to no term limits, given that he has the confidence of the assembly.

entities.title: Will Durant
entities.description: William James Durant was an American writer, historian, and philosopher. He became best known for his work The Story of Civilization, 11 volumes written in collaboration with his wife, Ariel Durant, and published between 1935 and 1975. He was earlier noted for The Story of Philosophy (1926), described as "a groundbreaking work that helped to popularize philosophy".

entities.title: Alexander Dubček
entities.description: Alexander Dubček was a Slovak politician who served as the First Secretary of the Presidium of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia (KSČ) from January 1968 to April 1969. He attempted to reform the communist government during the Prague Spring but was forced to resign following the Warsaw Pact invasion in August 1968.

Her long career spanned more than 70 years from 1921 until her death and she was a major figure in the Harlem Renaissance. heading: Deaths

entities.title: Ann Dunham
entities.description: Stanley Ann Dunham was an American anthropologist who specialized in the economic anthropology and rural development of Indonesia. She was the mother of Barack Obama, the 44th President of the United States. Dunham was known as Stanley Ann Dunham through high school, then as Ann Dunham, Ann Obama, Ann Soetoro, a.k.a. Ann Sutoro, and resumed her maiden name, Ann Dunham, later in life.

He specialised in political economy, political theory, and development studies and is well known for his research on development and democracy in Africa. Donald Macintyre, in an obituary in The Independent, described him as "the most recognisable and respected broadcast political journalist since World War II."

The attorney general serves as the principal advisor to the president of the United States on all legal matters. The attorney general is a statutory member of the Cabinet of the United States.

entities.title: Chief Rabbi
entities.description: Chief Rabbi is a title given in several countries to the recognized religious leader of that country's Jewish community, or to a rabbinic leader appointed by the local secular authorities. Since 1911, through a capitulation by Ben-Zion Meir Hai Uziel, Israel has had two chief rabbis, one Ashkenazi and one Sephardi.

entities.title: Commonwealth of Nations
entities.description: The Commonwealth of Nations, generally known simply as the Commonwealth, is a political association of 54 member states, almost all of which are former territories of the British Empire. entities.title: House of Lords
entities.description: The House of Lords is the upper house of the Parliament of the United Kingdom. Membership is by appointment, heredity or official function. Like the House of Commons, it meets in the Palace of Westminster.
